title: @Riot Tantram: Would it help to track punished players across multiple accounts if...
body:
1. the League Client kept a hidden/encrypted file somewhere in the program folder that held a unique identifier so that Riot could tell if a user was simply using multiple accounts from the same client?

2. the League Client traced it's route to check if the connection is the same as that used by other accounts from the same location.

I believe that these techniques could be combined with existing profiling techniques used by Riot to match alternate accounts back to their owner. I believe they would help to ensure that punishments would stick instead of just forcing a player to play on their 'alt.'

Discuss in the comments, and feel free to share any other ideas you might have for how to address this issue.

replies.body:
I actually suggested this solution in another thread yesterday. It sounds great but there are some inherent problems with it.

- Different users using the same computer could be affected
- Hiding a file on the client side computer could be figured out and exploited
- This doesn't work if the player used a different computer

I see what you mean, but I have some ideas about solutions.

1. It would not automatically result in punishment, instead it should be combined with other tracking techniques such as matching heat-maps and champion-pools in order to build up a case surrounding the accounts on that connection. That said I do understand the issue of multiple users on the same machine or connection, as shown in my comment: "How should this be handled to prevent mistaken punishments against internet cafes, gaming lounges or college dorms where a user could bring down punishment on other users nearby?"

2. Should be simple enough to hide multiple files and encrypt them all, just to make it harder to tell which to figure out. Also keeping the encryption keys and algorithms on the server and only working with the file there would prevent the user from decrypting it. Then whenever the game patches (or at random times if Riot wants to really enforce it) the client could upload the file back to the server for decryption. If the file were messed with then it can be reasonably assumed that the user modified the file. Additionally a new file encrypted differently could be downloaded to replace it in order to ensure that the user could never decrypt it.

3. Trace Route would be able to track the machine through its connection route, even different computers will still have to use the same network, so if a user has similar heat-maps, champion pools, and other factors tracked by Riot then Riot may be able to verify if it is the same user on a different machine.

I'm not saying the proposed system is foolproof. But I do think that it is reasonably believable / reliable for the purpose of flagging potential accounts to watch out for.

Don't get me wrong, I'm all about keeping the perma banned assholes as far away as possible. I was just playing devil's advocate.

I posted my comment before you posted yours concerning the internet cafe/multiple users quandary.

I think this idea actually could work when used in conjunction with heatmaps and champion pools like you suggest. I never thought of combining them personally.

Now all we need is Tantram to come and weigh in here to let us know how viable he thinks this solution is, and present us any problems that we couldn't foresee not being part of the program behind the scenes.

I think we may actually be getting somewhere here!

Using an encrypted finger print file in combination with other pre-existing detection tactics like heatmaps and champion pools it could be an actual effective way to lock players out of the game that refuse to reform or follow the rules.

If we can effectively lock out players that refuse to follow rules, it may work as incentive for players that previously were immune to reform because they could always just create a new account.

I was more just defending my idea, it's different on the boards than in-game. That was all I was trying to say.

The boards operate differently from League of Legends. And the other systems of tracking and profiling that would work on league do not necessarily work on the boards.

Essentially, they have less to work with when trying to match accounts on the boards than they do to match accounts in the game client.

The point of creating a complicated system of profiling is to make it too complicated and not worthwhile for the average toxic player to bother working around it. There's not much that can be done to truly prevent a particularly determined player from continuing to use the system, but for most, this would be enough.

It would take a lot of steps done carefully and in the right order, which is way more effort than most players are willing to put forth after receiving a punishment.
